unnormalised: The UIDAI has announced that it will now allow linking of educational and employment identifiers to Aadhaar for streamlined verification processes. This initiative aims to reduce the hassle of carrying multiple documents and provide a single, verifiable source of information. The linking will be voluntary and requires consent from the individual.
normalised: The U-I-D-A-I has announced that it will now allow linking of educational and employment identifiers to Aadhaar for streamlined verification processes. This initiative aims to reduce the hassle of carrying multiple documents and provide a single, verifiable source of information. The linking will be voluntary and requires consent from the individual.

unnormalised: According to sources, this integration would mean that details like your student ID (e.g., 2020/IITD/CSE/123) or employee ID (e.g., TCS1234567) can be linked to your Aadhaar number. This could potentially simplify processes such as university admissions, job applications, and background checks, reducing paperwork and saving time.
normalised: According to sources, this integration would mean that details like your student I-D (e.g., two thousand twenty slash I-I-T-D slash C-S-E slash one hundred and twenty three) or employee I-D (e.g., T-C-S one two three four five six seven) can be linked to your Aadhaar number. This could potentially simplify processes such as university admissions, job applications, and background checks, reducing paperwork and saving time.

unnormalised: To safeguard privacy, the UIDAI clarified that only authorized entities will have access to the linked information and that data will be encrypted and stored securely. Individuals will also have the option to unlink their educational and employment identifiers at any time. The procedure will involve OTP verification via registered mobile no. or biometric authentication.
normalised: To safeguard privacy, the U-I-D-A-I clarified that only authorized entities will have access to the linked information and that data will be encrypted and stored securely. Individuals will also have the option to unlink their educational and employment identifiers at any time. The procedure will involve O-T-P verification via registered mobile number or biometric authentication.

unnormalised: Several educational institutions, including JNU and DU, and corporate firms like Infosys and Wipro, have expressed interest in exploring the potential benefits of this system. Concerns remain, however, regarding data security and the potential for misuse. The UIDAI assures that stringent measures are in place to prevent any unauthorized access or data breaches.
normalised: Several educational institutions, including J-N-U and D-U, and corporate firms like Infosys and Wipro, have expressed interest in exploring the potential benefits of this system. Concerns remain, however, regarding data security and the potential for misuse. The U-I-D-A-I assures that stringent measures are in place to prevent any unauthorized access or data breaches.

unnormalised: Critics point to the mandatory nature of Aadhaar in other contexts, expressing concern that this voluntary linking could become de facto mandatory in the future for educational and employment opportunities. The debate continues. This pilot project is slated to begin on 15/07/2024.
